title: Last days of 2023 ‘unsettled’ weather says Met Office with ‘colder-than-average’ January on the way - Glasgow Live
text: The last days of 2023 are set to be unsettled with strong winds, rain and [snow](https://www.glasgowlive.co.uk/all-about/weather) battering parts of the country. Low pleasure areas are set to push in from the west on Saturday as conditions brought by Storm Gerrit continue to ease towards Hogmanay. Friday will bring some brighter spells to [Glasgow](https://www.glasgowlive.co.uk/news/glasgow-news/) and the central belt as wind and rain continues to affect some areas of Scotland. Saturday will bring some rain and snow with the city seeing some showers on Sunday and Monday. Steven Ramsdale is a [Met Office](https://www.metoffice.gov.uk/weather/forecast/gcuvz3bch#?date=2023-12-28) Chief Forecaster. He said: “This system is likely to bring a range of weather including hill snow. READ MORE: [ Pint sized bottles of wine to hit Glasgow shelves following Brexit rule change ](https://www.glasgowlive.co.uk/news/pint-sized-bottles-wine-hit-28359270) READ MORE: [Huge Glasgow Central Station queues as passengers travelling to London stuck due to cancellations](https://www.glasgowlive.co.uk/news/glasgow-news/huge-glasgow-central-station-queues-28360206) "Heavy rain will spread across all but the far north on Saturday affecting similar areas previously affected by Storm Gerrit. However, this rainfall will be a step down from that seen during Storm Gerrit.” Looking further ahead into 2024, there is low forecast confidence. Nick Silkstone is a Met Office Deputy Chief Forecaster. He said: “Through to mid-January, there is a signal for a shift in the pattern compared to the winter so far, with more settled and colder-than-average conditions becoming increasingly likely.” Weather in Glasgow Friday: Mainly dry and sunny. A few showers across Argyll and along the coast, these wintry on hills. Cold. Maximum temperature 6 °C. Saturday to Monday: Dry start but outbreaks of rain and snow spreading north for a time.
